candidates.title: Pass all Shanghai and Cancun tests
Initial integration of legacytests
candidates.body:
Also added `RuntimeBaseBackend::can_create` to prepare for EIP-7610. Although this is never formally adopted it's apparently already integrated into tests.

However, EIP-7610 is not always possible to implement. For some chains, checking whether storage is empty is too expensive. We therefore provide options to either have EIP-7610, or not have it, via the `can_create` function.

candidates.title: Init `evm-compat` and move mainnet related functions to `evm-mainnet`
More mainnet convenience functions and some generic refactoring
candidates.body:
* Move `Handle` as input type parameter (so that it's possible to impl multiple handle type for the same instance).
* Add `evm-mainnet` with some more mainnet convenience functions.

candidates.title: Convenience functions for mainnet
candidates.body:
* Add `transact_mainnet` as a wrapper for `transact` with most parameters fixed.
* Move `InMemoryBackend` to `evm` so it can be used outside of `jsontests`.

candidates.title: Change suffix back to -dev after release
Reorganize interpreter crate
candidates.body: Flatten it, so that we don't get too much nesting when doing imports.

candidates.title: Async precompile contracts
candidates.body:
Users of Rust EVM often implements complex custom precompiles. It is a long requested feature that those precompiles can also do custom call/create just like a normal EVM contract. In the past, this is not easy to do. EVM engines need to use a heap-based call stack (for deep calls), and in this case, a call/create would not continue the function, but must return first. After the call stack finishes executing subcalls, it then "feedbacks" the result to the current level.

This PR implements a way to make it possible. It uses the `async fn` Rust construct that returns a `Future`. Inside the future, we just do a bit of kongfu via `Cell` and `Rc` to capture "action" and receive "feedback". If the action is a call/create, then it traps and the result is later returned via the feedback value. All of those are transparent to the user -- one would only need to write an async function and invoke call/create just like a normal function call.

Apart from a few heap allocations and usage of `Cell`, `Rc`, this method of implementation is performant. However, one needs to make sure that they don't use other async libraries. In general, only `submit.submit` should be `await`ed.

On the call stack level, one needs to implement the trait `standard::Resolver` and customize its `Interpreter` type, usually by creating an enum that choosing from either `EtableInterpreter` and `FutureInterpreter`. It then checks for precompile address and return `FutureInterpreter` for async precompiles.

candidates.title: Change version suffix back to -dev after release
Fix ecrecover and modexp impl
candidates.body: Some edge cases are wrong, so we simply use the impl from revm.

candidates.title: Precompile compliance fixes and EIP-161 RIPEMD issue
Fix various compliance issues
candidates.body: Mainly issues in EXTCODEHASH (about account existence) and CREATE nonce increase.

candidates.title: Add Makefile and format TOML files
candidates.body:
## Description

Adds a standard Makefile and TOML formatting to CI.

candidates.title: Init evm64 feature
candidates.body: `rust-evm` allows customization of literally all aspects of EVM. As a result, new (unstable) features can be added / removed with ease without affecting any other parts of the code. This one initialize the template for `evm64` feature. The actual `eval` and `gasometer` etables are yet to be filled out.

candidates.title: Swich interpreter stack from H256 to U256
Add support to DecodeWithMemTracking
candidates.body:
# Description 

- Add support to `DecodeWithMemTracking` that is required to upgrade another dependencies that depends on this one to polkadot `stable2503`

- Also upgrade ethereum to include my latest commit

Similar to what I did with https://github.com/rust-ethereum/ethereum/pull/62

candidates.title: add transact_create_force_address
candidates.body: Add support for creating contracts with predetermined addresses.

candidates.title: Finalize v0.42.0 release
candidates.body:
- Update rust version in `rust-toolchain.toml`, otherwise build fails.
- Enable CI in `v0.x` branch.
- Fix several missing version bumps.
- Missing opcode flags that cause the jsontests to fail.

candidates.title: Upgrade the versions of `primitive-types` to `0.13` and `rlp` to `0.6`
Check `exit_substate` result before return
candidates.body:
Always verify `exit_result` before updating the state (set_code). @sorpaas 

Note: A patch for the v0.41.1 version.

candidates.title: Use macros to reduce boilerplate code
Cancun self destruct changes (EIP 6780)
candidates.body:
This PR implements the new changes for the `selfdestruct` function as outlined in [EIP-6780](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-6780). 

The new EIP allows for contract deletion only within the same transaction that created it. Otherwise, the `selfdestruct` function will simply transfer all Ether in the contract account to the target address.

Another change introduced by this EIP is that when `selfdestruct` is not called in the same transaction that created the contract, if the target address is the same as the contract address, there is no net change in balances. Unlike the previous specification, Ether will not be burned in this case.

candidates.title: Initital implementation of overlayed backend
candidates.body: An overlayed backend, provide `TransactionalBackend` and `RuntimeBackend` implementation for anything that implements `RuntimeBaseBackend`.
